title: Boris Johnson to warn ‘back deal or back delay’ as Brexit talks go down to wire
text:
EU leaders are talking this weekend about Brexit

Brexit talks will continue today between British and EU officials amid rising speculation a deal is on the cards.

The EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier gave the green light yesterday for intensive discussions to begin.

Officials are attempting to break the deadlock over the Irish border issue and, if successful, the UK could leave the EU on October 31.

Today’s talks between EU leaders come ahead of a crunch European summit on Thursday and Friday (October 17 and 18)

Any new agreement would need to be signed off by all 27 EU member states by then.

Boris Johnson is set to call a vote on Saturday which will determine the fate of the UK (Picture: AP)

On Saturday, October 19, the UK Parliament will sit at a weekend for the first time in almost four decades.

This morning there were reports there could be a final Brexit vote during the so-called ‘Super Saturday’ sitting.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Prime Minister Boris Johnson is expected to challenge MPs to back any deal secured with Brussels or force through yet another delay.

If the vote passes, parliament will sit for seven days a week in order to push legislation through both the House of Commons and House of Lords before the end of the month.

A source told the Times: ‘It’s decision time for MPs.

‘They can either back the deal or back a Brexit delay.

‘It will be a binary choice.’

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and his MPs will have a choice to make next week (Picture: PA)

Remain MPs have made a no-deal Brexit illegal and are still said to be planning to try and force through a vote on a second referendum.

It paves the way for a mass rebellion by Labour and opposition MPs.

Labour have yet to officially comment but MP Peter Kyle, who has hinted at a confirmatory vote being attached to Mr Johnson’s deal, said: ‘It’s crunch time.

‘We are well and truly into the end game.

‘This country needs this resolved and parliament is determined to give this the resolution that the country expects.

‘We will seek to attach a confirmatory ballot to any deal he brings to the Commons.’

Thursday’s talks between Ireland’s Taoiseach Leo Varadkar (L) and Britain’s Prime Minister Boris Johnson appeared to go well (Picture: AFP)

Government officials are remaining tight-lipped over an apparent breakthrough on a divorce settlement, in stark contrast to leaks earlier in the week.

Advertisement

Advertisement

But there is intense speculation the issue has turned a corner after Thursday’s talks between Mr Johnson and his Irish counterpart Leo Varadkar appeared to go well.

The unexpected thawing of tensions saw the pair say a deal looked ‘promising’ although there was ‘still a way to go.’

Their vague optimism was matched by European Council President Donald Tusk who said he had received ‘promising signals.’

It is understood that Mr Johnson has resurrected plans drawn up by Theresa May for a customs partnership between the EU and the UK.

He has, however, insisted that Northern Ireland be able to take advantage of any new trade deals that the UK can strike with other nations.

That would allow the border on the island of Ireland to remain open, something crucial to the Good Friday Agreement that secured peace after four decades of troubles.

It would essentially mean politically Northern Ireland is in a customs union with the EU but that it would be administered by the UK.

A source familiar with the situation told The Times: ‘Northern Ireland effectively stays in the EU’s customs union but for the purposes of trade it’s in the UK’s customs union.

‘It’s a fudge.’

DUP Leader Arlene Foster still needs to give her backing to a deal (Picture: PA)

On Friday, Mr Johnson said he was adamant he would not do anything that damaged the ability of the ‘whole of the United Kingdom’ to take full advantage of Brexit.

Advertisement

The PM still needs to ‘sell’ the deal to the DUP, whose support will be crucial if he is to get his deal through a bitterly divided Parliament.

He also needs to persuade Tory MPs who repeatedly voted against Mrs May’s deal in Parliament, leading to her resignation.

Ministers believe, however, that Mr Johnson is better placed to persuade Eurosceptic Tories and the DUP.

The DUP have hinted privately they could be supportive but leader Arlene Foster publicly warned they would only agree if the measures were in the ‘long-term economic and constitutional interests’ of Northern Ireland.

Yesterday the pound hit its highest level since Mr Johnson took office and the stock markets rallied amid rising hopes of a breakthrough.
